member.name: M:TweetSharp.Twitter.Fluent.Extensions.UseProxy(TweetSharp.Twitter.Fluent.IFluentTwitterConfiguration,System.String)
member.summary:
When this configuration option is called, the query request is sent via the specified proxy URL, rather than directly to Twitter.
Currently, the .NET default of using the Internet Explorer defined proxy as a default for all outgoing requests is in place, but may change before the version 1.0 release.
member.param: The URL of a proxy to use
The current position in the fluent expression
member.returns: The current position in the fluent expression

member.name: M:TweetSharp.Twitter.Fluent.Extensions.UseTransparentProxy(TweetSharp.Twitter.Fluent.IFluentTwitterConfiguration,System.String)
member.summary: Uses the transparent proxy instead of calling twitter directly

member.name: M:TweetSharp.Twitter.Fluent.Extensions.UseGzipCompression(TweetSharp.Twitter.Fluent.IFluentTwitterConfiguration)
member.summary: When this configuration option is called, the query request is sent as GZIP encoded content, and automatically decompressed when received. This is useful for requests that retrieve a large number of results, but will increase bandwidth on smaller requests.
member.param: The current position in the fluent expression
member.returns: The current position in the fluent expression

member.name: M:TweetSharp.Twitter.Extensions.TwitterExtensions.AsError(TweetSharp.Twitter.Model.TwitterResult)
member.summary:
This method attempts to cast an XML or JSON string into a instance. If this method is not successful, null is returned.
Twitter is now returning two inconsistent schemas for errors. One is a collection. In this case, only the first element is returned, because we have only seen single entry collections to date.
At some point, we assume the API will change across the board, and we will change this deserialization method to follow suit.
member.param: The XML or JSON input to convert

member.name: T:TweetSharp.TestTwitterClientInfo
member.summary: Client info class for the test runner.

member.name: T:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo
member.summary: This class provides meta-data for your specific Twitter application, that is used to identify your client to Twitter, store OAuth credentials for all future request, and in some cases define a transparent proxy to redirect API calls to.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo.ClientName
member.summary: This is the name of your client application. It is used to identify your client when a user updates their status, or when your application makes a Twitter Search API request.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo.ClientVersion
member.summary: This is the version of your application. This is meta-data only, and not used by Twitter for client processing.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo.ClientUrl
member.summary: This is the URL of your application. This is meta-data only, and not used by Twitter for client processing. Your application's URL is stored by Twitter when you apply for a 'Source' attribute or register your application for OAuth.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo.ConsumerKey
member.summary: If your client is using OAuth authentication, this value should be set to the value of your consumer key. This avoids having to provide the key in every query.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo.ConsumerSecret
member.summary: If your client is using OAuth authentication, this value should be set to the value of your consumer secret. This avoids having to provide the secret in every query.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TwitterClientInfo.TransparentProxy
member.summary: Since you are communicating from the client-side, this value should point to a proxy that is configured to work transparently (API methods are identical other than the domain), allow cross-domain access, and understand TweetSharp custom headers.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.TestTwitterClientInfo.TwitterAccepts
member.summary: Gets the meta header for acceptable Twitter content types returned by the API. This is used mainly to guarantee that tests work with URL-encoded values, though this should be vestigial by now as Twitter has promised to return this value for all real Accepts responses.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.Twitter.Service.TwitterSearchOptions.Location
member.summary:
Returns tweets by users located within a given radius of the given latitude/longitude. The location is preferentially taking from the Geotagging API, but will fall back to their Twitter profile.
You cannot use the near phrase operator via the API to geocode arbitrary locations but you can use this geocode parameter to search near geocodes directly.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.Twitter.Service.TwitterSearchOptions.LocationRadiusMiles
member.summary:
Returns tweets by users located within a given radius of the given latitude/longitude. The location is preferentially taking from the Geotagging API, but will fall back to their Twitter profile.
You cannot use the near phrase operator via the API to geocode arbitrary locations but you can use this geocode parameter to search near geocodes directly.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.Twitter.Service.TwitterSearchOptions.LocaleIso
member.summary: Specify the language of the query you are sending (only ja is currently effective). This is intended for language-specific clients and the default should work in the majority of cases.

member.name: P:TweetSharp.Twitter.Service.TwitterSearchOptions.LanguageIso
member.summary: Restricts tweets to the given language, given by an ISO 639-1 code.
